title: The Experimental Web: Alternative Visions of the Internet, London
body:
**[Future Inventions: The Experimental Web](https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/1271686381199?aff=oddtdtcreator)**

Join us for the third offering in our Winter/Spring Programming, a study group exploring the theme of The Experimental Web: Alternative Visions of the Internet.

The world wide web was once believed to the world’s solution to creating a global village, promising to connect millions across time and place and exist as a vast directory of knowledge. Yet today’s reality looks nothing like this with social networks being the dominant pathways into the internet. Long gone are the days of random discovery and ‘surfing the web’ - instead, our realities online are largely directed by SEO and algorithms. As of 2022, More than half of all network traffic [(57%) ](https://www.techmonitor.ai/hardware/networks/big-tech-accounts-for-over-half-of-global-internet-traffic)was attributable to Google, Netflix, Facebook, Apple, Amazon, and Microsoft. What does it mean that our digital roads mostly drive through these Big Tech giants? How does the design of the internet reflect the values and logics of capitalist / colonial actors?

In response to this, web designers, artists, and organisations are increasingly experimenting with creating ‘the small web’ (other terms include ‘the tiny internet’, ‘handmade web’, and ‘slow web’), which described an internet outside of Big Tech Social Media, often designed to encourage curiosity and exploration and reflect the niche interests of the creator(s).

This month, we will be focusing on the history of the internet from its military roots to public development, the infrastructure that supports it, and the social/artistic interventions that are reimagining what the web could look like.

**How is this going to go?**

We’ll begin with an overview of the theme by delivering a brief and engaging introductory lecture on the history of the internet, network infrastructure and artistic interventions in making the web a safer and more interesting place to be. From here, we will collectively read the essay [On Digital Gardens: Tending to Our Collective Multiplicity by Annika Izora ](https://www.deemjournal.com/stories/digital-gardens)and then break out into smaller groups for guided discussion around our relationship to the internet and how we might reimagine it to better meet our needs/the needs of our communities. After small group discussion, there will be a larger share-out around our learnings and we will close. All of this will be explained further on the day.

**No pre-reading or preparation necessary!** If you are curious, we have collated these resources: https://www.are.na/decolonize-the-art-world/future-inventions-the-experimental-web
